awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Research and Training at the Intersection of Number Theory and Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Prime numbers have been a natural object of study for thousands of years and now play a foundational role in modern encryption systems for digital communications. Despite their long study, many questions about the distribution of prime numbers remain unsolved. Primes are also intertwined with the study of class numbers, which appear in many number-theoretic settings. Class numbers have been studied for 200 years, but still remain largely mysterious, although precise conjectures have been developed. Seemingly far away on the mathematical spectrum,  Radon transforms quantify the distribution of the "mass" of functions along lower-dimensional surfaces; they are a critical part of the theory underlying Computed Tomography medical imaging. The study of Radon transforms is a central area in harmonic analysis with far-reaching connections both to the Carleson operator, which was instrumental in answering a historic question on Fourier series, and to the new world of discrete arithmetic operators, which blends harmonic analysis with number theory. This project, which is at the intersection of number theory and harmonic analysis, explores and connects all of these themes. During the course of the work, the project will contribute to the mathematical community through training postdocs, a graduate summer school, and mathematical outreach activities for children.

The major aims of this research center on five projects at the intersection of number theory and harmonic analysis. First, new bounds relating to the divisibility of class numbers of number fields of arbitrary degree will be obtained. Second, new bounds will be obtained for short character sums, which historically provided an important subconvexity result for L-functions, and now in a multi-dimensional setting have the potential to impact problems involving counting integral solutions to Diophantine equations. Third, in the realm of Diophantine equations, new variations on the circle method, and closely related questions on multi-dimensional oscillatory integrals, will be developed. Fourth, new results for discrete operators will be proved by adapting number-theoretic methods to the setting of harmonic analysis. Finally, a systematic investigation of Carleson operators with polynomial phases and Radon-type behavior will be carried out.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on research in mathematics, specifically in number theory and harmonic analysis.  Counting solutions to multi-variate polynomial equations with integral coefficients is a central problem in number theory, with a long history. This project led to new methods for counting solutions to Diophantine equations using sieves and the circle method. The project also led to new methods and results that elucidate the size of torsion subgroups in class groups of number fields. These works led to an increased understanding of tight connections between this problem and other central open problems, such as the vanishing properties of L-functions in families, counting number fields with fixed degree and bounded discriminant, and counting number fields with fixed degree and fixed discriminant. The project additionally led to new bounds for short character sums, and revealed a surprising connection between a well-known method in number theory and concepts in harmonic analysis.

Because of the Fourier transform, exponential sums and oscillatory integrals are ubiquitous in analytic number theory and harmonic analysis. Work during this project exploited number-theoretic properties of exponential sums to prove counterexamples to pointwise convergence for certain solutions of dispersive PDE's such as the Schrodinger equation. Other work introduced the study of the Hardy-Littlewood majorant property for exponential sums to the context of arbitrarily high dimensions. Related to oscillatory integrals, this project studied maximally modulated Radon transforms over hypersurfaces defined by quadratic forms, and proved new cases in which such operators are bounded. At the interface between number theory and harmonic analysis, the PI wrote expositions explaining new developments (such as decoupling, the study of discrete operators, and a pointwise convergence problem in PDE's), and characterized generalized notions of orthogonality. This interface is an exciting area of current research that is leading to new progress on questions that have been unsolved for decades.

During the period of the project, the PI advised independent study projects and collaborated on research projects with undergraduate students and graduate students and jointly mentored postdocs. The PI disseminated the findings of the project at research seminar series and conferences, both domestic and international. During the period of the project, the PI organized four summer schools for graduate students and postdocs as well as a trimester program in number theory and harmonic analysis, in order to facilitate learning by young researchers and strengthen collaboration and innovation in the research community. Participants at two of the summer schools (initially planned for 2020 and 2021) were anticipated to be funded by the project, but due to the pandemic these summer schools had to be adapted to an online format. The project contributed support to a writing workshop for mathematical researchers in 2020 and to a workshop in 2022 for undergraduates interested in applying to PhD programs in the mathematical sciences. The PI engaged local school-age children in math-enrichment activities. In collaboration with an editorial board, the PI founded a new journal, Essential Number Theory, that aims to deepen the impact of the most important developments in number theory, by making sure they are communicated to a broad audience of students and researchers.
